comments.html: A similar problem is IP fragmentation (although that should not happen too often if MTU discovery is working properly), which is handled with the Virtual Fragmentation Reassembly feature introduced in IOS release 12.3(8)T.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: But problem really is not caused by load-sharing. It is because many things aren't prepared for out ouf order packets and it can just happen without load sharing, because that is how Internet works. You can fix your configuration by using per-destination, but it won't fix remote locations.
comments.name: Unknown

comments.html:
As I wrote in a comment to another post, I really cannot see packets getting reordered unless you use per-packet load sharing or weird QoS setup that treats packets from the same flow differently.

If there's something I'm missing, I would be glad to hear about it.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: Well, it shouldn't ;) Obviously something in the forwarding path is reordering packets (probably due to per-packet ECMP/LAG instead of per-session or per-address ECMP/LAG). Capture traffic at various points along the forwarding path to figure out where they get reordered.
